Lauren:

Thanks for your contribution. I have begun using the term "behavior
under test" rather than "class" or "object" to describe the thing I'm
testing. If each behavior is implemented nicely as a single method,
then so much the better.

>3) Being both a developer and a SQA engineer, I often write unit tests
for
>other people's code.

You're a brave person to write tests for other people's code. Every
time I do that, I end up writing an article in protest. This was the
genesis of "Use your singletons wisely". (I need to plug my old
articles from time to time.)

When testing existing code, the goal is verification/validation and not
design improvement. Once we have confidence in the correctness of the
behavior, we can begin to improve the design.

J. B. Rainsberger,
President, Diaspar Software Services
